web_research.query: What are the best algorithms for irregular polygon packing optimization?
web_research.finding:
Irregular‑polygon packing (also called irregular 2‑D nesting) seeks to place a set of non‑convex polygons into one or more bins or a strip while minimizing waste or the number of bins used. Because the exact problem is NP‑hard, most practical solvers rely on sophisticated heuristics or meta‑heuristics that combine a fast constructive phase with a powerful improvement phase ([Frontiers](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmech.2022.966691/full)).

The most widely used constructive approaches are based on **No‑Fit‑Polygon (NFP)** calculations and simple placement rules. An NFP‑based nesting algorithm that introduces trace lines for lower time‑complexity and a *lowest‑gravity‑center* placement policy outperforms the classic bottom‑left rule and can handle arbitrary rotations and holes ([ACM](https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/1141277.1141507)). A related 2‑level algorithm builds a collision‑free region (CFR) and then places pieces inside it, achieving high utilization on heterogeneo
